Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Long-Term Studies of Seedling and Small Sapling Community Dynamics in a Neotropical Forest
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests possess the most diverse plant communities on earth. How hundreds of similar species can coexist, without a few dominant species outcompeting all others, is a major unresolved question in ecology. Processes occurring early in a tree?s life are thought to be critical for allowing such large numbers of species to coexist. This project extends a twelve-year study that tests multiple hypotheses proposed to explain plant species coexistence through long-term measurements of seedlings and saplings in lowland tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island, Panama. The fate of over 100,000 seedlings of 350 tree, shrub and woody vine species will be followed within a mapped forest inventory plot.

Tropical forests provide critical ecosystem services upon which humans depend, but nonetheless are being lost at an alarming rate. Results from this study will help to predict and to mitigate the effects of global change on forests and their critical ecosystem services. Data collected on regeneration requirements for hundreds of tropical plant species will be useful in silviculture, forest management and biodiversity conservation. The project promotes international scientific collaboration and provides training and jobs for undergraduate and graduate students and early career biologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests are well-known for their high biological diversity — hundreds of different tree species can be found at a single site in the tropics. Explaining how so many plant species coexist in tropical forests, without one or a few competitively dominant species taking over, has long posed a challenge to ecologists. There have been many hypotheses proposed to explain how so many tree species can coexist in tropical forests, and most of them focus on early life stages (i.e., seed, seedling, sapling stages). Suppressed by low light levels, herbivory, and competition with adult trees, individuals of most tropical tree species spend decades in the forest understory as seedlings or small saplings, if they survive at all — very few seedlings will reach maturity and reproduce. Understanding dynamics at these early life stages is essential because they act as a bottleneck in the life cycle, such that seedling survival serves as a strong filter on the composition of future plant communities. In addition, patterns of seedling survival will likely also shape the response of tropical forests to shifts in climate. Therefore, determining the key factors driving seedling survival is critical for understanding, predicting, conserving, and managing tropical forest diversity, composition, and function, both now and in the future.

This project extended a long-term study of seedling and sapling dynamics (i.e., recruitment, growth, and survival) in a tropical forest that sought to (1) evaluate multiple hypotheses of plant species coexistence in order to understand how high levels of diversity are maintained in tropical forests, and (2) assess effects of year-to-year variation in rainfall on tropical seedling dynamics to provide insights into how tropical tree species will respond to shifts in climate. Through this project, we have been monitoring seedlings and saplings in 20,000 1x1 m2 plots in the Barro Colorado Island (BCI) 50-ha Forest Dynamics Plot in central Panama (9o9’ N, 79o51’W). To date, we have completed 14 censuses of these seedling plots, resulting in a database containing information on the recruitment, growth, and survival of >160,000 individuals of >400 tree, shrub, and liana species.

Results from this project have significantly advanced our understanding of the factors that shape tropical tree communities. Specifically, through analyses of these long-term seedling data, we have shown that species coexistence in the tropical forests likely results from both conspecific negative density dependence (i.e., lower survival when an individual is surrounded by neighbors of its own species, which prevents any one species from becoming too common) and species' abiotic niche partitioning (i.e., different species use the environment differently, reducing competition). In addition, we found that species vary widely in their response to low water availability, with some species highly sensitive to drought stress and therefore more sensitive to predicted shifts in precipitation. Analyses of data from this project have also revealed the importance of the seedling stage in structuring tropical forests. For example, we found that conspecific negative density dependence is much stronger at the seedling stage compared to later life stages. We also demonstrated that tree species distributions result from differential seedling survival among species across habitats that vary in soil moisture. In addition, we used data from this project to examine tropical tree species’ life history strategies (i.e., different ways in which a species can successfully grow and survive in a given environment) and identified a new life history trade-off axis: a trade-off between recruitment and seedling performance vs. growth and survival of larger individuals. In total, the project has resulted in ten publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals (between 2105 and 2018). The impact of this project is further reflected by the fact that project findings have already been included in two college text books.

The project also provided training and hands-on research experience in a tropical forest for one undergraduate, one graduate student, and ten field assistants. In addition, the project contributed to training in the statistical analysis of large, long-term data sets: project data were used in analyses and subsequent scientific publications by multiple PhD students and postdoctoral researchers. This study also provided openly-available data on hundreds of tropical plant species and contributed to scientific infrastructure through the establishment of a network of permanent seedling plots that facilitated several other research projects at the site.
